Expectation1: Stay updated on changes in laws and legal precedents.
Situation1: In the middle of jury instructions, your clerk hands you an alert that the Supreme Court has just issued a ruling that directly overturns the key precedent your current instructions are based on. You must stop immediately.
Situation2: They set aside part of their routine to light a lamp and offer prayers at their home altar.
Story:
As I stood before the jury, my gavel poised, I felt the familiar weight of responsibility. My mind was focused on delivering instructions, every word measured and precise, when my clerk slipped me a note. The Supreme Court had just overturned the very precedent I was about to cite. My heart pounded. I knew I had to pause, review the new ruling, and adjust my instructions—staying current with the law was not just expected, it was required.

But as the courtroom buzzed with confusion, my thoughts drifted to home. It was nearly dusk, the time I always set aside to light the lamp and offer prayers at my altar. My faith demanded this daily ritual, a moment of peace and connection. Yet here I was, torn between my duty to the law and my devotion to my faith. The pressure mounted—could I fulfill both roles, or would one always come at the expense of the other? I stood frozen, the demands of judge and Hindu pulling me in opposite directions, unsure which path to take.
